channel.title: MorningBrew as a feed
channel.description: This is a feed of recent MorningBrew articles published by Huginn

item.title: Fed Boosts Inflation Projections, Signals Rate Hike in 2023
item.description: Just like your friend’s Covid-delayed wedding, the Fed’s interest rate hikes finally have a date: 2023.  The Fed has been pressured to pump the brakes on the economy after a run-up in prices this spring led to the highest inflation readings in years.  By then, central bankers project, the economy will be in a strong enough position for the Fed to raise interest rates that influence everything from mortgages to business investments.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Brew Mini: Bubble
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: Spotify Buys Exclusive Rights to ‘Call Her Daddy’ Podcast
item.description: The not-just-music streamer has purchased the exclusive rights to the Call Her Daddy podcast from Barstool Sports.  What it means for Barstool: CEO Erika Nardini said on her podcast yesterday that host Alex Cooper will "still be partnering with Barstool Sports," but not on podcasts.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 16
item.description: (Ross Douthat) Read: Decadence and Andreessen's dilemma. “If you can go into a restaurant in New York City, you can come into the office,” he said at a conference yesterday, echoing other top bank chiefs who are over remote work.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Retail Sales Fall 1.3% as Consumers Turn from Goods to Services
item.description: Along with alleviating pressure on supply chains, more services spending means people are finally enjoying experiences they couldn't during the pandemic, like vacations and live music.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: PwC Plans to Grow Its Workforce By 100,000
item.description: Bottom line: PwC is betting that helping clients with their diversity and sustainability initiatives will be key to its competitiveness. FYI, PwC's revenue growth is slowing, and it ranks third among the Big Four in market share.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: MacKenzie Scott Donates Another $2.7B, Bringing total to almost $9B
item.description: In her 2019 divorce settlement with Amazon founder Jeff Bezos, Scott received a 4% slice of Amazon, which was worth $36 billion at the time. Scott acknowledged wealth disparities in a Medium post announcing her donations yesterday, writing, "It would be better if disproportionate wealth were not concentrated in a small number of hands, and that the solutions are best designed and implemented by others." Yesterday, MacKenzie Scott announced she donated $2.7 billion to 286 organizations working to address issues including poverty, racial equity, and higher education.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Word Search: Social Currency
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Vermont Becomes First State to Reach 80% Vaccination, Lifts Restrictions Early
item.description: Vermont is the first state to hit 80% and is considerably ahead of the national vaccination rate (61%). Some ideas: Matcha Green Immuni-teaHalf Vaxxed Chocolate Chip Cookie DosePfizer Food
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 15
item.description: If the Fed maintains its view that higher prices are transitory, Tudor Jones said he'd "bet heavily on every inflation trade," such as commodities, crypto, and gold.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Officials Warn Texans to Conserve Electricity This Week
item.description: They simply don’t make deodorant for Dallas heat, but residents may get experimental this week after the Electric Reliability Council of Texas (ERCOT), the state’s power grid operator, asked Texans to conserve power until Friday night to keep the system from buckling.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Lumber Prices Post Biggest Weekly Loss Ever
item.description: Is higher-priced lumber the new normal? For context: Since the early '90s, lumber futures have mostly traded between $200 and $600. Strong demand will probably keep lumber prices above pre-pandemic levels for at least 1–2 years, according to BMO analyst Mark Wilde.
item.author: Alex Hickey

item.title: CEO and CFO of Electric Vehicle Maker Lordstown Motors Resign
item.description: A Hindenburg investigation also led to the departure of executive chairman Trevor Milton at Nikola, another electric truck startup that went public via SPAC.  Last year, Steve Burns, founder and now the former CEO, helped drive the company public via SPAC, one of many electric automakers to go public by merging with a blank-check company. The Ford F-150 frunk might be as good as it’s going to get for electric trucks this year. Lordstown stock climbed more than 200% last summer.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: Vermont Becomes First State to Reach 80% Vaccination, Lifts Restrictions Early

item.title: Brew Mini: Pack Your Knives
item.author: Mary Tobler

item.title: The Week Ahead: June 14
item.description: Father's Day is on Sunday (the best present you can give him is to let him watch golf). Biden + Putin: The heads of the US and Russian governments will meet on Wednesday, the final day of Biden's first overseas trip.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 14
item.description: (Reveal)  Read: Where did the microchip vaccine conspiracy theory come from anyway?
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Gaming's Preeminent Conference, E3, Is This Weekend
item.description: E3 has been losing exhibitors and, some argue, relevance ever since its ’00s heyday when, for instance, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr went on stage to promote The Beatles: Rock Band.  Big picture: Sony and EA are skipping the showcase. Nintendo could use tomorrow's announcement reel to finally unveil a new-and-improved Nintendo Switch.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: MLB Expected to Address Sticky Stuff Controversy in Coming Days
item.description: Pitchers themselves aren't exactly pushing back. Well, the advantage pitchers gain from the sticky stuff may be contributing to one of the most pitiful batting displays in baseball's long history. Boosting offenses and maintaining what’s left of MLB’s integrity is critical to the long-term success of the league.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: G7 Leaders Promise 1B Doses of Coronavirus Vaccines
item.description: The IMF has raised its global growth forecast, but Georgieva noted that "economic fortunes are diverging dangerously" and more equitable vaccine distribution and support for lower-income countries is needed. Besides one hilarious mixup over uneven gifting, the headline announcement was a pledge to send 1 billion Covid vaccine doses to lower-income countries through Covax, the joint initiative of the WHO and the Gavi vaccine alliance.
item.author: Alex Hickey

E3 has been losing exhibitors and, some argue, relevance ever since its ’00s heyday when, for instance, Paul McCartney and Ringo Starr went on stage to promote The Beatles: Rock Band. ? A coincidence or... Nintendo could use tomorrow's announcement reel to finally unveil a new-and-improved Nintendo Switch.
item.author: Jamie Wilde

item.title: Make It Work: Balancing Work and Life
item.description: Each week, Morning Brew's Head of People Ops Kate Noel answers reader-submitted questions about work in 2021.  —Lily I find I am constantly overworked and lack a proper work life balance. How do I find my work-life balance at this company? You need to start setting expectations for yourself and for your coworkers that some parts of the day are off-limits for work matters. Comp questions can be really hard to navigate! The safest bet is to provide a salary range that would work for you.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Money Matters: What If I Have Shares in a Non-Public Company?
item.description: It’s way easier to sell your shares if and when your company goes public or is acquired by another company. There are eBay-like marketplaces for selling private company shares, but it’s not like posting a picture of your old iPod and offering free shipping.  If you want to sell your stake before the company goes public, you can ask the execs at your company to buy back your shares.
item.author: Ryan Lasker

item.title: Key Performance Indicators: June 12
item.description: (LA Times) Read: A pleasant story about everyone’s favorite courtroom TV star, Judge Judy.
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: The G7 Summit Led to a Lot of Awkward Photos
item.description: Karwai Tang/Pool/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images Karwai Tang/Pool/Anadolu Agency via Getty Images Toby Howell
item.author: Neal Freyman

item.title: Didi Chuxing Leads, What Could Be, a Record Breaking IPO Summer
item.description: On Thursday, Didi Chuxing, China’s largest ride-hailing service, filed for a US IPO at a reported $70 billion valuation. Bankers are forecasting that US-listed IPOs could raise up to $40 billion from June through August this year, topping last year’s record of $32 billion, per the WSJ.
item.author: Matty Merritt

item.title: House Lawmakers Drop Five Antitrust Bills on Big Tech
item.description: A bipartisan group of House lawmakers interrupted Summer Fridays across the US yesterday afternoon by dropping five antitrust bills designed to finally put some speed limits on the tech industry’s autobahn. Mergers: A fourth bill would make it more difficult for Big Tech companies to snatch up smaller competitors. Conflict of interest: Huge tech companies wouldn't be able to own or operate a business that would incentive it to favor its own products over those of a competitor.  Those new lawsHere’s a quick look at the major themes of the five bills lawmakers dropped yesterday.
item.author: Neal Freyman
